newsitem.title: USA: Claudette Colbert's Oscar fails to attract bidders.
newsitem.headline: Claudette Colbert's Oscar fails to attract bidders.

text.p: Claudette Colbert's 1934 Oscar statuette failed to attract a high enough bid on Saturday and was withdrawn from a sale of Hollywood memorabilia at Christie's inaugural West Coast auction.

The prestigious auction house, which last week opened its first Los Angeles salesroom, had hoped Colbert's Academy Award for Best Actress for the comedy "It Happened One Night" would fetch between $150,000 and $200,000.
But it attracted no bids at the starting price and was pulled from the sale, which was entitled "Unforgettable Hollywood."
Marcia Hobbs, chairman of Christie's West Coast, said the gilded statuette still might be sold to an after-sale bidder following talks with the consigner.

"The feeling was that the sale, less than six months after the record sale of Clark Gable's Oscar for the same film, at a stunning price, might have put people off," Hobbs said. She said Gable's Oscar for the Frank Capra-directed film sold at Christie's for $600,000 last December.
It is not unusual for items that do not attract estimated bids to be put back on sale later. "It depends on the wishes of the consigner," she said.

The French-born Colbert died at her home in Barbados last July at age 92. The Oscar statuette -- the only Academy Award she won in her Hollywood career -- was believed to have been put up for auction by her estate. She had no children.
